Bishop: s claim that he was the "deciding vote" is exaggerated, as the GOP-authored bill wouldn't have advanced without the help of a Democrat.
To override a veto: the state House and state Senate each need three-fifths of their present members to support the idea. The Senate's override vote was 30 in favor and 20 opposed, meaning the effort advanced by one vote.
Gerry Cohen: former special counsel to the N.C. General Assembly, described Bishop's claim as a "non sequitur" and stated that it's misleading for him to say he cast the "deciding" vote.
